instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
This little MacBook come in with no power - no charge issue. Upon plugging into my 61w original apple charger it started charging It now charges. When you turn it on it chimes boot logo and even goes into OS. After some time it shuts down unexpectantly. it usually lasts from 5 seconds to about a minute with no warning.

Is this a software issue? What is the best way of diagnosing such a machine?
Also, I would like to point out that charge port and flex has also been changed and the board has been tested in another chassis to eliminate other hardware possibilities.

Have you guys seen anything like this before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"Is this a software issue?"
Boot your USB test OSX and see what happens...

You should try new BIOS, with clean ME.

Any history fault available?
Does it last if started in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
usb test usb does same thing.
interesting - in OS i booted. went to safari put on you tube watch video in full screen 15-20 minutes no problem. I exit full screen scroll up and down machine turn off.
no other history known. smc bypass is with power button extend press?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Yes, try that.
Next step, new BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: OMG :( i am brain dead - this is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not 00165 which is air :( i mixed board numbers in my head

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Any history available?
Put good flux and reflow CPU.
New BIOS with clean ME is still an option...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: unfortunately no history but no sign of drop or liquid. I have artifacting after running one hour at login screen small green line

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You should have RAM, or CPU issue.
That board is so small, that you will probably finish reballing it completely.
Be aware with the hot air, you can destroy it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: So what temp reflow.. for CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
200 Celsius degrees should be good, if you want to burn the crap only (undernearh BGA chips).
This also requires to use quality flux.
Enough for an internal issue of the BGAs too.
Melting solders requires 230 degrees, but maybe no need that.

Be aware, I talk about board temps.
To reach these values you need to set up hot air station at 400 maybe, or even more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: do you think a preheater is required?
